hobby.message: Found any new political literature lately?
Origami helping you dodge the spiral?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I fold origami... from scrap forms mostly. It helps me think... quietly.
neutral_answer: No trouble, not really. Just some delays at the checkpoint.
I do origami. Works for stress, in theory.
System hiccups make it hard to focus.
Lots of noise outside lately, hard to work on small folds.
Bit slow getting here. System outages all over since Halden... since last week.
I fold paper, mostly complex patterns—origami, if you know it.
Usually helps me relax.
Last night, couldn’t get through a single model.
Hard to concentrate with the new drone routes so close.
Clear streets mostly. Got held at the gate for a while—systems glitching since Halden’s death.
Anyway, I unwind folding complex origami. Tessellations, modular builds, that sort of thing.
Usually I use old bulletins or scrap.
Last night, drones kept circling—noisy and out of sync, system resets maybe.
Ruined more paper than usual.
Makes a mess of a pattern, that kind of background noise.
Took the long way—less crowded, fewer drones tonight.
The city’s been weird since Halden died. Systems don’t settle.
I try to tune it out, folding origami—doing that for years.
Big, intricate pieces, not just cranes. Lately hydrangea lattices.
I save the better scraps from work.
Last night, the patrols’ timing was off, made me rush folds, messed up the sequence.
It’s hard to find that focus when the city feels—restless.
It’s been unpredictable lately. Used to take fifteen minutes to walk here. Now it’s double.
After Halden’s… accident, I find routine matters get disrupted in small ways.
Origami is how I used to calm my mind after shifts—choose a tricky pattern, fold until the city faded out.
I’m meticulous with the steps: hydrangea tessellations, modular assemblies, sometimes even polyhedra if I find enough good paper.
Usually I salvage discarded internal bulletins—thicker paper, holds a crease better.
But last night, the system glitches and off-schedule drones made it impossible to settle in.
Lost track of my folds, ruined a sheet I’d saved for weeks.
It’s strange, how the system’s cracks show up in something as pointless as a piece of paper.
hobby_answer: Simple waterbomb base. Nothing special, just habit.
Paper jams more lately. Supply's inconsistent since those BCI system resets.
Lost a few sheets last week when the power flickered.
Guess it’s harder to focus when the city’s glitching.
People notice more when routines change.
Did a traditional crane, but made mistakes. Hard to concentrate after system failures.
The outages throw off my sense of quiet time, you know?
It’s odd, the sound of drones stopping mid-pattern.
Feels like even small hobbies are affected now.
Paper’s rougher too. Central supplies seem off-rhythm.
Only folding from memory, not the new complex stuff.
Folded a hydrangea mosaic last. The creases didn’t line up like usual.
System failures kept breaking my focus—the drones reset all evening.
Ran out of decent paper after supply delays; had to salvage bulletin scraps.
Feels like every pattern falls apart more quickly, these days.
Halden’s death didn’t just break the Directorate—living feels off-balance too.
You notice things go wrong in the background, even with tiny hobbies.
It makes the city feel... unstable, even at home.
It was a hydrangea tessellation—ambitious, but the folds came out uneven.
Couldn’t ignore the BCI outages; power flickered just as I started creasing.
I save dispatch bulletins for paper, but the last batch was damp from storage problems.
Every time the security drones glitched outside, my hands shook a bit.
It’s funny, I used to time folding with the city’s quiet hours. Can’t anymore.
Feels like after Halden’s death, nothing runs to schedule, even hobbies.
I ruined two pieces from simple nerves. That never used to happen.
I guess all this instability creeps in, no matter what you’re doing at home.
Last? Hydrangea mosaic, but I botched it—city wouldn’t settle down long enough.
Origami’s my escape—following precise steps keeps me steady.
System resets after Halden’s death wrecked my pattern: lights flicker, drones stall, everything out of sync.
Even paper feels scarce—paper runs get delayed when BCI permissions are slow.
It’s odd—I used to fold through the night, counting on system routines to shield me.
This week, drone patrols stuttered right outside my door. Made me second-guess every crease.
I smudged two sheets from nervous hands. Hard to admit.
When infrastructure goes off-beat, even tiny rituals unravel. Maybe that’s why I notice more.
The world used to feel logical. Now, nothing does—not even the things that kept me calm.
